xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This work is supported by the funding under the National Natural Science Foundation of China (21673041 and 21973013), National Natural Science Foundation of Fujian Province, China (2020J02025). The authors also thank ?Chuying Program? for the Top Young Talents of Fujian Province. The TEM and HAADF-EDX tests were based on the resource of State Key Laboratory of Photocatalysis on Energy and Environment, Fuzhou University. The authors also thank the Testing Center of Fuzhou University for the Raman and PL spectra experiments.

This work is supported by the funding under the National Natural Science Foundation of China ( 21673041 and 21973013 ), National Natural Science Foundation of Fujian Province, China ( 2020J02025 ). The authors also thank “Chuying Program” for the Top Young Talents of Fujian Province. The TEM and HAADF-EDX tests were based on the resource of State Key Laboratory of Photocatalysis on Energy and Environment, Fuzhou University. The authors also thank the Testing Center of Fuzhou University for the Raman and PL spectra experiments.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) The sketch map of the WN-QDs@C synthesis process. (b) The XRD pattern of precursor WO3/C3N4. (c) The XRD and (d) Raman spectra of the WN@C (inset of (c) is the unit cell of WN). (e–f) TEM images of WN-QDs@C (inset of (e) shows the size distribution of WN-QDs and inset of (f) shows the particle morphology of WN-QDs). (g) HRTEM image of WN-QDs@C. (h) HAADF and (i–k) elemental mappings of W, N and C, respectively.

(a) The XRD patterns of ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS. (b) DRS spectra of WN@C, ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS, respectively. (c) BET surface area and (d) pores size distribution of ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS, respectively.

(a) TEM and (b) HRTEM image of 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS (The right calculated spacing lattice fringe is corresponding to the selected rectangle in (b)). (c) HAADF image and (d) elemental mappings of W, N, Zn, In, S and C, respectively.

(a–b) The comparison of ZIS, WN@C and composites with different loading amount of WN@C, respectively. (c) The time-dependent photocatalytic hydrogen evolution of WN@C and ZnIn2S4, respectively. (d) The photocatalysis stability of 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS under visible light irradiation (λ ≥ 400 nm).

(a) C 1 s spectra, (b) N 1 s XPS spectra and (c) W 4 f XPS spectra of WN@C and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS, respectively. (d) Zn 2p, (e) In 3d and (f) S 2p XPS spectra of ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS, respectively. (g) The work function of ZnIn2S4 and WN@C, respectively. (h) The sketch map of the photocatalytic effect of WN@C and the proposed photocatalysis mechanism (BIEF is built-in electric field).

(a) Top and side views of the interfacial model of WN@C, color code: W, purple; N, blue; C, grey. (b) Calculated Gibbs free energy diagram of the HER on different sites of WN@C. (c) The average photocatalytic performances in first two hours on different catalyst under irradiation of 500 nm monochromatic light. (d) LSV plots of ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS in 0.2 M Na2SO4 solution with the scan rate of 50 mV s−1. (e) The temperature dependence of reaction rate on ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS, respectively. (f) The schematic diagram of the E
a difference on ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

(a) The transient photocurrent i-t curves (λ ≥ 400 nm) and (B) EIS spectra of ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS, respectively. (C) The proposed mechanism of the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution over 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS.
The comparison of different parameter for ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS.

head.ce:title: Highly efficient and durable core-shell catalyst with dual functions: Tungsten nitride quantum dots encapsulated in ultra-thin graphene

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Research Institute of Photocatalysis, State Key Laboratory of Photocatalysis on Energy and Environment, College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350116, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Research Institute of Photocatalysis, State Key Laboratory of Photocatalysis on Energy and Environment, College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Research Institute of Photocatalysis, State Key Laboratory of Photocatalysis on Energy and Environment, College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350116, China

ce:section.ce:para: Energy issues and environmental problems have caused the growing focus of the whole world and searching for alternative, sustainable and clean energy has been one of the most important subjects [1,2]. There is no doubt that the lightest reactive gas hydrogen is the ‘star energy’, containing large density of carbon-free energy [3,4]. Among the many ways of getting hydrogen, photocatalytic water splitting by photosensitive semiconductor system is a promising strategy, which is first developed by Fujishima and Honda [5].

For an efficient photocatalysis system, co-catalyst is always the fundamental part whatever the reaction is a half process or not [6–8]. Transition metal-based compounds (such as chalcogenides, carbides, phosphides) have emerged to be the ideal substitute of noble metal co-catalyst for their high electronic conductivity, earth-abundant reserves, similar electronic structure with noble metals, and high melting point [9–11]. Recent studies have shown that metallic transition metal nitride can also act as the potential co-catalyst for photocatalytic reaction. For instance, W2N has similar co-catalytic effect with W2C and WS2 in the aspect of improving the photocatalysis performance of C3N4 [12]. Yang and his coworkers designed a dual-phase nitrides Co4N-WNx with high conductivity and rich active sites, which is superior to Pt [13].

Meanwhile, the transition metal-based nitrides also own high density of carriers and small band gap, meaning that they may be good candidates for photocatalysis applications, such as water splitting or contaminant degradation under long wavelength light illumination [14,15]. Yang and his coworkers have confirmed that the tungsten nitride with low work function performed enhanced plasmonic effect on near-infrared photocatalysis [16]. However, for the bulk metallic WN, the light absorption and the characteristics of large carrier density cannot be utilized efficiently due to the severe carriers recombination, which is not propitious to the photocatalysis reaction.

To solve the problems above, many efforts to reduce the scale of materials have been made in the last decades, such as the development of nanosheets (NSs) [17,18], nanorods (NRs) [19] and nanowires (NWs) [20]. Nanomaterials with shorter transfer path of carriers and more light absorptive capacity make them more attractive than bulk materials in applications. Due to their three-dimensional size as low as several nanometers, quantum dots (QDs) materials have been developed and extensively used in the areas of liquid crystal display, cell imaging, cellular delivery and catalysis [21–24]. During the synthesis and activity evaluation processes, however, QDs tend to aggregation due to the collision of numerous nanoparticles, which is still harmful for the efficient separation and utilization of carriers. Hence, separating QDs into respective cells by some conductive materials to form typical core-shell structure is a desirable strategy. And the ultrathin conductive graphene is a promising candidate. Here we propose to package WN quantum dots (WN-QDs) separately with the ultrathin graphene to construct the unique core-shell structure. This core-shell structure shows several advantages. First, the enormous agglomeration of WN in the process of calcination nitriding or photocatalytic reaction can be avoided as much as possible. Second, in consideration of the conductive graphene shell and the WN with low work function, an efficient and all-solid-state Z-scheme system can be constructed by combining with other semiconductors with large work function. Third, conductive graphene can act as the electron reservoir to extract from the adjacent component and facilitate the separation of photocharges. Last, the conductive ultrathin graphene shell can act as the efficient electron transfer channels to interflow mutually and shorten the charges’ transfer distance greatly.

With large atomic utilization ratio and rich surface functional group, WN-QDs may own the properties of co-catalytic and photocatalytic effects simultaneously. After the formation of core-shell structure, WN@C is also expected to show the dual functions of cocatalysis and photocatalysis. It is believed that WN@C will has a bright future in the application of photocatalysis. Besides, as far as we know, the systematic and detailed study on the co-catalysis and photocatalysis effect of WN@C has rarely been reported. Taking into account of the composition and synthesis approach, most of the core/shell quantum dots reported are Cd-based colloid materials [25,26]. It is general to adopt successive ion layer adsorption and reaction (SILAR) method to get the core/shell quantum dots, which includes many experimental steps [27,28]. Besides, it is necessary to store the obtained colloid quantum dots in dispersant to stabilize. Complicated synthesis method and the possible noble metal both increase the relative production cost. While the WN-QDs@C reported here is composed of non-noble-metal based materials and the synthesis approach is facile relatively, meaning that the production cost is low. With respect to the environmental concerns, there may eject some methanol gas and low doses of HCl during the synthesizing process of our work, which shows little effect on the environment. In these works of colloid materials reported, numbers of organic compound (such as hexane) and stabilizer (such as 3-mercaptopropionic acid) have been adopted, which may affect the environment.

Herein through an in situ calcined nitridation method, we have successfully constructed an efficient and durable catalyst that is composed of the unique WN-QDs core encapsulated in ultrathin graphene shell. For the first time, the co-catalytic and photocatalytic effects of WN@C quantum-sized core-shell structure are systematically studied and discussed. Interestingly, combined with typical semiconductor ZnIn2S4, the optimal composite shows 61 times than that of bare ZnIn2S4 and 12 times than that of WN@C on photocatalytic performance of hydrogen generation (λ ≥ 400 nm) and high stability for 99 h without apparent decrease. The calculations and analysis demonstrated that the WN@C mainly acts as a co-catalyst in long wavelength range (λ ≥ 500 nm) with the absence of energetic electrons, while it showed photocatalytic effect in the lower wavelength of visible light range (400 nm ≤ λ ≤ 500 nm). All-solid-state Z-scheme system promotes the efficient utilization of charges in WN for photocatalysis water splitting under visible light irradiation. Kinetic studies revealed that the good photocatalytic activity is synergistically facilitated by the large reduced apparent activation energy (E
a ), the lower overpotential of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the reduced ∆G
*H and the inhibited recombination of photocharges. This work is expected to show the light on the development of other bifunctional metallic photocatalyst and the design of other QDs-based core-shell materials.

Typically, 304.2 mg ammonium tungstate was dissolved in 50 mL deionized water (DI) water and marked as solution A. 1 g melamine was suspended into 100 mL methanol and stirred for 30 min. Then 10 mL 0.1 M HCl was dropwise added into the suspension with serious stir and marked as solution B. After that, solution A was dropwise put into B and then the suspension was heated to 80 °C to evaporate the solvent. Then the white powder was put into a tube furnace to be nitrided reduction pyrolysis under temperature control. It was heated to 500 °C with the rate of 5 °C/min and then hold for 2 h. Later it was heated to 700 °C with the rate of 5 °C/min and then hold for 4 h. The calcination process was always kept in Ar atmosphere with a flow rate of 100 mL/min. After natural cooling to room temperature, the black powder was washed by ethanol and DI water several times and then put in a vacuum oven to dry out.

A series of WN@C/ZnIn2S4 composites were synthesized through a modified hydrothermal method [29] and marked as x wt% WN@C/ZIS (x referred to 0.1, 0.5, 2 and 5, respectively). For instance, during the synthesis of 0.5 wt% WN@C/ZIS, 2.1 mg WN@C was suspended in 60 mL ethanol under ultrasonication. Then 219.5 mg zinc acetate, 763.8 mg indium nitrate and 601.04 mg thioacetamide were dissolved in the suspension. After stirring for 10 min, the suspension was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 160 °C for 24 h. Then the reactor was cooling down and washed several times with DI water and ethanol.

The schematic diagram of the synthesis way is proposed and shown in Fig. 1a. Ammonium tungstate and melamine act as the W source and N source, respectively. The coated graphene layer comes from the segmented pyrolysis of melamine-containing precursor C3N4 and the WN is derived from the nitridation of pre-synthesis intermediate WO3. The crystal structure and composition of the final sample were conducted by X-ray diffraction (XRD). As shown in Fig. 1b, the XRD spectra of the precursor can be well ascribed to WO3 (PDF#71–2141) and C3N4 (PDF#50–1249), respectively. While the XRD of the as-obtained powders (Fig. 1c) belongs to the cubic WN (PDF#75–1012, space group Pn-3 m). Notably, a broad peak can be seen at the position of almost 26° (marked in orange rhombus), which is probable to be the graphene carbon [30,31]. The inset in Fig. 1c is the unit cell model of cubic WN. In addition, the Raman spectra of the obtained sample (Fig. 1d) shows the typical bands at 1325 cm−1 (D-band) and 1601 cm−1 (G-band), which comes from the disordered carbon structure and ordered sp2 carbon, respectively [32,33]. These can confirm the existence of graphene carbon in WN. Then scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was adopted to investigate the morphology of the as-prepared WN@C. As illustrated in Fig. S1 of the Supporting Information, it exhibits small particle morphology.

The detailed structures and morphological features were investigated through transmission electron micrograph (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron micrograph (HRTEM) images. From the Fig. 1e–f and Fig. S2a–b we can see that the WN particle is composed of enormous quantum dots (QDs) and the average size is at 2.5 nm (inset histogram in Fig. 1e). The detailed structure shows that the nanoparticles are encapsulated in a shell with a brighter contrast (Fig. 1g and Fig. S2c–d) [34]. The HRTEM image clearly uncovers that the shell is constituted by 1–2 layers of graphene. The distinct lattice fringe of the QDs in Fig. 1g and Fig. S2d is 0.24 nm, which is corresponding to the (111) crystallographic plane of the cubic WN. Besides, the high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) (Fig. 1h) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) element mapping (Fig. 1i–k) were investigated. The element mappings demonstrate that the QDs are composed of W, N and C and that all of them are dispersed well. These results demonstrate that the WN-QDs encapsulated in ultrathin graphene are successfully obtained.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Structure and property of the composite
ce:section.ce:para: The SEM and XRD were adopted to analyze the morphology and construction of ZnIn2S4. It demonstrates small particle-like structure (Fig. S3) and the XRD peaks can be ascribed to hexagonal ZnIn2S4 (PDF#65–2023), showing the similar peaks with the literatures [29,35]. After combining with 2 wt% WN@C, the XRD peak shows no apparent difference ( Fig. 2a), probable deriving from the universal dispersion or the relatively low diffraction intensity of WN. This demonstrates that the low loading content of WN@C will not change the bulk crystal phase of ZnIn2S4. The optical property of ZnIn2S4 and the 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS composite are obtained from the DRS spectra (Fig. 2b). Pure ZnIn2S4 owns the band edge absorption at almost 550 nm and the introduction of WN@C enhances the absorption in the range of λ ≥ 400 nm obviously. Hence, the visible light spectrum is adopted in the later evaluation process of photocatalytic performance. To investigate the surface area and the porosity analysis of the samples, Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area and pore size distribution were conducted. As presented in Fig. 2c, both two samples have large BET surface area and similar type of N2 adsorption/desorption equilibrium. Compared with pure ZnIn2S4, the slight reduction on BET surface area of the composite may be derived from the partial coverage of pores by WN@C after loading. It has been reported that this type of adsorption isotherm belongs to the Type IV with typical H4 hysteresis loops, which is usually accompanied by the narrow slit-like pores [36]. The results of the pore size distribution demonstrate the existence of plentiful mesoporous (Fig. 2d). Therefore, the relatively lower ratio of pore distribution for the composite can account for the slight reduction of BET surface area aforementioned.

The detailed structure of 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS composite was also observed by TEM ( Fig. 3a) and HRTEM. The composite shows nanoparticle structure. As shown in the HRTEM (Fig. 3b), the 0.29 nm lattice fringes (marked with yellow rectangle) correspond to the (104) plane of ZnIn2S4, while the 0.21 nm lattice fringes (marked in lilac rectangle) correspond to the (200) plane of WN. To further investigate the element distribution, the HAADF (Fig. 3c) and EDX element mapping analysis (Fig. 3d) were also conducted. Except for the Zn, In and S, the uniform W, N and C can also be seen in the element mappings. It demonstrates that the WN@C is successfully loaded on the surface of ZnIn2S4.

Then the photocatalytic performance of water splitting under visible light irradiation (λ ≥ 400 nm, 300 W Xe lamp) over different photocatalysts were tested. From the Fig. 4a–b we can see, the photocatalytic activity of WN@C with different loading amount shows volcanic-type distribution. Under visible light irradiation (λ ≥ 400 nm), the pure ZnIn2S4 shows low activity with 3.2 μmol h−1 g−1, and the hydrogen generation rate of pure ZnIn2S4 tends to reduce after 8 h under visible light illumination (Fig. 4c). This is probably derived from the serious recombination of photo-induced charges. WN@C shows H2 generation rate of 16.8 μmol h−1 g−1 while no H2 is detected from the bare graphene (Fig. S4), signifying that the photocatalytic effect mainly comes from visible-light-responsive WN-QDs. However, the photocatalysis stability of WN@C is also not good and can only keep for 4 h. The reason why the activity of WN@C is higher than that of ZnIn2S4 can be attributed to more photocharges, which had been reported before [14,37]. After loading 0.1 wt% WN@C, the activity expresses order of magnitude increase. When the loading amount comes to 2 wt%, the activity gets to the highest value of 196 μmol h−1 g−1 (almost 61 times than that of ZnIn2S4). Further increasing the content of WN@C leads to the reduction of activity, which may be derived from the agglomeration of WN@C during the synthesis process. Then the optimal composite was adopted to carry on the activity stability test. Intriguingly, the as-prepared 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS can generate hydrogen for as long as 99 h without apparent reduction, during which no extra sacrificial agent is supplemented (Fig. 4d). This good manifestation may be derived from the greatly inhibited recombination of photocharges and indicates the excellent stability of 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS. Besides, the XRD pattern (Fig. S5) and morphology (Fig. S6) before and after longtime reaction shows no distinct change. All of these exhibit that the as-prepared optimal composite owns good activity and stability.

Then, the electronic structure and interfacial interactions for the samples were well studied through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 5a, both of WN@C and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS contain C-C/CC, CN and CO peak at 284.60 eV, 286.32 eV and 288.72 eV, respectively [38,39]. Besides, it is worth noting that there is a new peak at 281.65 eV for 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS, which may belong to metal-C (Zn-C or In-C), showing the existence of the intense interaction between WN@C and ZnIn2S4. As shown in Fig. 5b, the lowest binding energy is attributed to the WN bond while the peak at 400.64 eV and the peak at 402.09 eV belong to the NC bond for WN@C and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS, respectively [20]. In addition, the peak at 402.20 eV for WN@C may be ascribed to the absorbed water. The missing of NO bond in the composite may derive from the wastage of the absorbed water during the recombination process with ZnIn2S4. Notably, the peaks of N 1 s for the composite shift to higher binding energy in comparison with WN@C. In the high-resolution mode (Fig. 5c), the W 4 f spectra of both samples can be deconvolved into quadruple peaks. The doublet peaks for lower binding energy (32.52 eV, 36.07 eV for WN@C and 32.92 eV, 36.50 eV for 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS) are attributed to WN bond of WN, while higher ones (34.46 eV, 38.20 eV for WN@C and 35.08 eV, 38.77 eV for 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS) belong to WO bond, which may be derived from the absorbed water in ambient environment [12,16,40]. Besides, compared with WN@C, all peaks of the composite shift to the direction of higher binding energy, which means that the electron cloud around W in 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS is decreasing [41,42]. The Zn 2p XPS (Fig. 5d) spectra of 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS shifts to lower binding energy in comparison with bare ZnIn2S4 while the In 3d (Fig. 5e) and S 2p (Fig. 5f) show no shift. It suggests that the electrons density around Zn increase and the metalC bond mentioned before is Zn-C, which can connect graphene with ZnIn2S4 robustly. The shifts of binding energy are reasonable based on the analysis followed. The work function of WN is reported as low as 3.6 eV [16,43,44], meaning that the electrons of WN at static conditions can flow out after incorporation of other components with large work function. The work function of monolayer or bilayer graphene is reported to be 4.4 eV [45,46], which is larger than that of WN. That is, the electrons can flow from WN to graphene and the built-in electric field (BIEF) can be formed in the interface. As a result, the Fermi levels of WN and graphene tend to the equilibrium state and the band structure of WN will bend up. The band gap of cubic WN is reported to be 1.55 eV [14]. Hence, the band structure of WN will bend up under the BIEF (Fig. S7). After incorporation with ZnIn2S4, the electrons density around W and N in the composite are reducing while that of Zn is increasing, implying that the electrons in the static state may flow from WN to ZnIn2S4 due to the Fermi level difference.

To further research the charge transfer way, the work functions of ZnIn2S4 and WN@C were conducted through a Kelvin probe system and the result is shown in Fig. 5g. The work function of ZnIn2S4 demonstrates almost 120 mV larger than that of WN@C, meaning that the Fermi level of ZnIn2S4 is lower than that of WN@C. This fact verifies the aforementioned electrons flowing way, leading to the formation of BIEF pointing from graphene to ZnIn2S4. The band structure of ZnIn2S4 will bend down, which is beneficial for the excited electrons on the CB of ZnIn2S4 to flow to the conductive graphene shell and then to WN under light irradiation. Notably, this work function difference is smaller than that between WN and graphene. As a result, it can lead to the band of WN bends up severely, which will inhibit the electrons of WN from flowing out at some extent [47,48]. In addition, the WN@C shows noticeable activity in the short wavelength range (λ = 420 nm or 435 nm), which verifies the photocatalytic effect of WN-QDs (Fig. S8). Therefore, the visible light photocatalytic mechanism is proposed and the mechanism follows the all-solid-state Z-scheme (Fig. 5h). All of these confirm that the intense contact and the bonding connection are formed in the interface between WN@C and ZnIn2S4.

Under the effect of band bending and BIEF, the photo-induced electrons can flow into WN@C to participate in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). To unravel the HER mechanism on WN@C and the co-catalytic effect of WN, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out based on an interfacial model (denoted as WN@C) consisted of N-terminated WN(111) covered with one atomic layer of graphene ( Fig. 6a). More computational details with the tests of the number of graphene layers and the terminations of WN-(111) can be found in Fig. S9-S10. It is well known that the Gibbs free energy of H adsorption (denoted as ∆G
*H ) was usually adopted as an indicator for evaluation of HER activity. Thus, we calculated the ∆G
*H values of HER on different sites of WN@C. The calculation results in Fig. 6b show that the carbon sites on both the outer and inner sides of the graphene layer have an average ∆G
*H as high as 1.82 eV. While on the surface of WN-(111) covered with one graphene layer, the ∆G
*H values on N and W sites are only 0.06 and 0.13 eV, respectively, close to the optimal value (~0 eV) of ∆G
*H for ideal HER catalyst [49,50]. Obviously, the HER process is more likely to take place at the N sites while the graphene is nearly inactive for this catalysis. That is, in the constructed WN@C/ZIS photocatalyst system, the co-catalytic effect of WN-QDs is better than that of graphene and the WN core coupled with C shell may be an efficient co-catalyst. Besides, the wavelength-dependent hydrogen generation rates of ZnIn2S4 and WN@C at 500 nm and 550 nm were conducted and shown in Fig. 6c. As seen, both bare ZnIn2S4 and WN@C show no detectable hydrogen generation in the first two hours, which may be due to the severe recombination of the photo-charges. At the same time, the 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS composite exhibits 6.28 and 1.44 μmol h−1 g−1 under two wavelengths of light, respectively. The absorption edge of ZnIn2S4 is located at almost 550 nm, i.e. ZnIn2S4 can be excited under 500 nm or 550 nm irradiation. Hence, the WN@C core-shell structure mainly plays the co-catalyst role here. Based on the analysis before, WN-QDs coupled with graphene is an efficient co-catalyst at long wavelength light irradiation (λ ≥ 500 nm). Besides, the optimal composite shows 0.67% solar to hydrogen (STH) under AM 1.5 G light irradiation (Table S2).

To further investigate the co-catalytic effect of WN@C, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves and the kinetic study were conducted on bare ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS composite. The composite shows much enhanced cathode current in comparison with ZnIn2S4 (Fig. 6d), meaning the sharply reduced overpotential of hydrogen evolution after combination with WN@C. It can be ascribed to the excellent co-catalytic effect of WN@C. Furthermore, the kinetic study of ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS in photocatalytic system were conducted to identify the co-catalyst role of WN@C. The apparent activation energy (E
a ) of ZnIn2S4 for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution is calculated to be 21.20 kJ mol−1, according to the Arrhenius plots (Fig. 6e). While the E
a of the composite is as low as 5.06 kJ mol−1, almost 76% reduction in comparison with pure ZnIn2S4, which is consistent with its photocatalytic performance. Therefore, the WN@C can boost the visible light photocatalysis H2 generation by sharply decreasing the E
a of the reaction (Fig. 6f). This can indirectly show that the active sites where the surface redox reaction occurred change from ZnIn2S4 to WN@C, which leads to the largely promoted photocatalytic performance [51]. The performance of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution over previously reported ZnIn2S4-based with our work is shown in Table S3.

The dynamics of the charges behavior was further investigated by the room temperature photoluminescence (PL). After combination with WN@C, the PL emission peak of the composite shows much weakened, demonstrating the inhibited photo-induced charges recombination (Fig. S11) [52,53]. Hence, the largely inhibited recombination of photocharges is responsible for the good activity and stability of the 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS composite. Photoelectrochemical properties of ZnIn2S4 and 2 wt% WN@C/ZIS were tested through i-t plot and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) spectra for comparison. As shown in Fig. 7a, the composite expresses largely enhanced photocurrent density during the light illumination (λ ≥ 400 nm) in comparison with pure ZnIn2S4, meaning that more photo-charges are detected. Besides, the EIS of the composite (Fig. 7b) demonstrates smaller semicircle arc than that of ZnIn2S4, verifying the conductive WN@C can facilitate the charge transportation at the interface between WN@C and ZnIn2S4. Therefore, as an effective channel for charge transfer, the ultrathin conductive graphene combines with ZnIn2S4 and WN-QDs to construct the all-solid-state Z-scheme system.

In summary, we reported an efficient catalyst composed of WN quantum dots encapsulated in ultrathin graphene shell (WN@C) and studied their dual functions (photocatalytic and co-catalytic effects) in photocatalytic water splitting. The results demonstrated that the WN@C mainly act as a co-catalyst in long wavelength range (λ ≥ 500 nm), while it showed photocatalytic effect in the lower wavelength of visible light range (400 nm ≤ λ ≤ 500 nm). As an efficient electron transfer channel, the ultra-thin graphene layer facilitates the efficient utilization of the enormous carriers in WN and the inhibition of charge recombination greatly. At the same time, the unique core-shell structure can prevent tungsten nitride nanoparticles from agglomerating, greatly shorten the transfer distance of charges and effectively utilize the photo-induced electrons during the photocatalytic reaction. The photocatalytic activity of the optimal synthesized composite shows 61 times increase than that of pure ZnIn2S4 and 12 times than that of WN@C. Besides, it can split water from the lactic acid solution with a long-term stability of more than 99 h. This work is expected to show light on the other core/shell quantum dots and dual functional catalyst for photocatalysis reactions.

Fan Gao: Conceptualization, Methodology, Investigation, Writing – original draft, Writing – review & editing. Qiang Wan: Methodology, Investigation and Calculation. Jie Yuan: Methodology, Investigation. Rui Lei: Investigation. Sen Lin: Investigation, Funding acquisition, Writing – review & editing. Ping Liu: Supervision, Project administration, Funding acquisition, Writing – review & editing, Resources.
